user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CountSemTimedWait_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CountSemTimedWait_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, uint32 msecs)
{
    struct timespec                     ts;
    int                                 result;
    OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_count_sem_table, *token);

    /*
     ** Compute an absolute time for the delay
     */
    OS_Posix_CompAbsDelayTime(msecs, &ts);

    if (sem_timedwait(&impl->id, &ts) == 0)
    {
        result = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else if (errno == ETIMEDOUT)
    {
        result = OS_SEM_TIMEOUT;
    }
    else
    {
        /* unspecified failure */
        result = OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    return result;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CountSemTimedWait_Impl:
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t OS_impl_count_sem_table[OS_MAX_COUNT_SEMAPHORES]
...
typedef struct
{
    sem_t id;
} OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t
...
void OS_Posix_CompAbsDelayTime(uint32 msecs, struct timespec *tm)
{
    clock_gettime(CLOCK_REALTIME, tm);

    /* add the delay to the current time */
    tm->tv_sec += (time_t)(msecs / 1000);
    /* convert residue ( msecs )  to nanoseconds */
    tm->tv_nsec += (msecs % 1000) * 1000000L;

    if (tm->tv_nsec >= 1000000000L)
    {
        tm->tv_nsec -= 1000000000L;
        tm->tv_sec++;
    }
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected the target function OS_CountSemTimedWait_Impl and all provided related code. MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 forbids using the standard-library function memcmp to compare null-terminated strings. None of the supplied code contains any call to memcmp, nor any other string-comparison functions (e.g., strcmp, strncmp) or manual bytewise comparisons that operate on C strings. The macro OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET and helper OS_ObjectIndexFromToken index by an integer field (obj_idx) — no string operations. OS_Posix_CompAbsDelayTime manipulates struct timespec fields (tv_sec, tv_nsec) and does not use or compare strings. The semaphore call (sem_timedwait) and errno handling do not involve memcmp or string comparisons. Therefore there are no code fragments in the provided sources that need investigation for Rule 21.14.
